newsitem.title: UK: C&W unravels Veba link, shifts focus.
newsitem.headline: C&W unravels Veba link, shifts focus.

text.p: British-based Cable & Wireless Plc, the international telecommunications group, on Friday confirmed its widely-expected plans to dissolve the bulk of its alliance with Germany's Veba AG and focus on its communications unit.

In a statement describing the move, C&W said it expected the sale of its 45 percent interest in Vebacom GmbH would raise 2.21 billion marks ($1.34 billion) and this, along with its buyout of Veba's half of Cable & Wireless Europe SA, would produce enhanced earnings by the year ending March 31, 1998.
C&W predicts an one-off pretax profit boost of 60 million pounds ($98.41 million) in the current financial year.

The end of the German venture will bring about a short-term cash boost for C&W, Britain's second-largest telcoms company after British Telecommunications Plc, and the company said it would allow an immediate concentration on the British-based Cable & Wireless Communications venture.

In its statement it said "the net cash receivable...will be used to reduce indebtedness of the group (which stood at 1.1 billion pounds at September 30, 1996) and to assist C&W in the development of its other businesses".

Share analysts who had anticipated this move over recent weeks have speculated that the termination will leave C&W in need of a new cornerstone for its continental European presence, where it will now be a thinly-spread, minor player.

"Europe remains a key strategic market for Cable & Wireless," the firm said in its statement, "and the company will concentrate its efforts in continental Europe on developing business which will strengthen and support Cable & WIreless Communications' position".
Veba said it will remain a shareholder in Cable & Wireless, retaining its current 10.4 percent stake. ($1=1.6506 Mark) ($1=.6097 Pound)
